text: ਸੋ ਬੂਝੈ ਜਿਸੁ ਆਪਿ ਬੁਝਾਏ ਗੁਰ ਕੈ ਸਬਦਿ ਸੁ ਮੁਕਤੁ ਭਇਆ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: He alone understands, whom the Lord inspires to understand. Through the Word of the Guru's Shabad, one is liberated.

transliteration.text: sō būjhai jis āp bujhāē gur kai sabad s mukat bhaiā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

text: ਨਾਨਕ ਤਾਰੇ ਤਾਰਣਹਾਰਾ ਹਉਮੈ ਦੂਜਾ ਪਰਹਰਿਆ ॥੨੫॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: O Nanak, the Emancipator emancipates one who drives out egotism and duality. ||25||

transliteration.text: nānak tārē tāranahārā haumai dūjā parahariā .25.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: The self-willed manmukhs are deluded, under the shadow of death.

translation.text: They look into the homes of others, and lose.

translation.text: The manmukhs are confused by doubt, wandering in the wilderness.

translation.text: Having lost their way, they are plundered; they chant their mantras at cremation grounds.

text: ਗੁਰ ਕੈ ਸਬਦਿ ਰਪੈ ਰੰਗੁ ਲਾਇ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: One who is filled with the Word of the Guru's Shabad enshrines love for the Lord.

transliteration.text: gur kai sabad rapai rang lāi .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: Attuned to the Truth, he goes to his home with honor.

text: ਸਾਚ ਸਬਦ ਬਿਨੁ ਪਤਿ ਨਹੀ ਪਾਵੈ ॥

translation.text: Without the True Word of the Shabad, no one receives honor.

section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: O Nanak, attuned to the Naam, their victory is celebrated. ||33||

translation.text: Through the Perfect Guru, one obtains the Naam, the Name of the Lord.

transliteration.text: pūrē gur tē nām pāiā jāi .

translation.text: The Way of Yoga is to remain absorbed in Truth.

text: ਬਾਰਹ ਮਹਿ ਜੋਗੀ ਭਰਮਾਏ ਸੰਨਿਆਸੀ ਛਿਅ ਚਾਰਿ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: The Yogis wander in the twelve schools of Yoga; the Sannyaasis in six and four.

transliteration.text: bārah mah jōgī bharamāē sanniāsī shi chār .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਗੁਰ ਕੈ ਸਬਦਿ ਜੋ ਮਰਿ ਜੀਵੈ ਸੋ ਪਾਏ ਮੋਖ ਦੁਆਰੁ ॥
section: Ramkali - Sidh Gosht (Conversations With The Perfected Masters)

translation.text: One who remains dead while yet alive, through the Word of the Guru's Shabad, finds the door of liberation.

transliteration.text: gur kai sabad jō mar jīvai sō pāē mōkh duār .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.
